poem:
Title: Snapshots of Love and Fear

Equal love rights bloom in Greece, late perhaps,
Yet, spring unfolds every petal in its time.
Malta, France, Spain, Portugal danced ahead,
As in the waltz of progress, no couple leads forever.

In the gray fog of England, Wales,
Death lurked biting in dog-shadows,
Sixteen victims, not mere seven,
Fear, can sharply distort perception's view.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • An article (Equal marriage vote brings new hope for Greece’s gay couples, 15 February, p26) said Greece was poised to become the first country in southern Europe to legalise same-sex marriage. In fact, Malta, Spain, France and Portugal are among the countries in the region to have already passed such a law. • There were 16 fatal dog attacks in England and Wales in 2023, not seven (Dogs that killed woman". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
